sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Italy ponders a new prime minister as Mario Draghi resigns after trying and failing to save his coalition government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: For the first time in 11 years, the European Central Bank raises rates all in a bid to battle inflation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Back on for now. Russian gas flows through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline to Europe once again, albeit at a reduced level. BACK ON FOR NOW. RUSSIAN GAS FLOWS THROUGH THE NORTH STREAM 1 PIPELINE TO EUROPE ONCE AGAIN, ALBEIT AT A REDUCED LEVEL. AND HERE IN THE CUBE, WE'LL TAKE A CLOSER LOOK AT FALSE CLAIMS THAT UKRAINIAN REFUGEES HAVE BLOCKED A MAJOR ROAD IN ITALY.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I'M HELENA HUMPHREY. IT IS GOOD TO HAVE YOU WITH US.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: ITALY'S PRESIDENT SERGIO MATARELLA HAS ANNOUNCED THAT HE WILL DISSOLVE PARLIAMENT, TRIGGERING EARLY ELECTIONS. It is good to have you with us. Well, Italy's President Sergio Mattarella has announced that he will dissolve Parliament, triggering early elections.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That's after Prime Minister Mario Draghi resigned earlier today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, following weeks of turmoil, Draghi's government imploded on Wednesday, with some members of his coalition refusing to back him in a confidence vote.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The former banker took office 17 months ago with a mandate to help the country recover after the COVID pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: His pro-EU stance and staunch support of Ukraine's war effort against Russia led to divisions within his coalition and towards its ultimate downfall.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, in Rome for us and across all of the latest developments is our correspondent, Georgia Orlandi.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Georgia, where are we in this process?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Because Draghi's resigned this time President Mattarella accepted his resignation so what happens next?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Hi Elena well already this morning President Mattarella's office issued a statement confirming that Draghi reiterated his resignation and saying that the government will stay on to manage current affairs. In other words, the current government will stay on to approve the few remaining key measures that have yet to be approved.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: As confirmed by President Mattarella, as you mentioned there, by dissolving Parliament now, under the current legislation, 70 days have to pass between the moment Parliament is being dissolved and the next general election which clearly means that those elections are very likely to happen on the 25th of September. Now there's been a debate over this whether or not this election could take place either on the 2nd of October or much earlier and it seems that Mattarella decided that these elections should take place earlier.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And that's because Italy's future government, by doing so, will be able to approve the budget bill.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We said that yesterday that clearly that has to be approved by and within a certain deadline.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Helena?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: All right, so snap elections potentially towards the end of September then.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Any names out there already as to who could step into Draghi's shoes? Well recent polls suggest that Italy's next prime minister could be from the centre-right bloc and those polls gave Italy's brothers of Italy which is actually one of Italy's main centre-right parties if not far-right parties, around 23% of the vote, which is quite significant. And in fact, the leader, Giorgia Meloni, well, there have been suggestions that Giorgia Meloni could actually become Italy's next prime minister. We said also, we commented on the fact that yesterday's debate actually showed how political parties have already embarked on what now seems to be a political campaign. And also that explains why the centre right block has been pushing so much for early polls. And that's because one of their intentions clearly was to cash in on their current popularity. But also let's remind ourselves that Italy's alignment under a new government under let's say a center right government would be much different especially when it comes to relations with Europe relations with other international partners. And clearly these could become a little bit of a game changer when it comes to having to deal with the war in Ukraine or the energy crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Helena?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Absolutely a key point there. Georgia Olandi in Rome, Georgia. Thanks very much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, to talk now more about the European reaction to Mario Draghi's departure,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: we can bring in our correspondent Maeve McMahon in Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Maeve, how is the news going down across Europe?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Good evening, Helena.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, here in Brussels, they're celebrating the Belgian national holiday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But you can be sure that those working for the EU institutions will not be celebrating tonight or enjoying those fireworks because the news is going down like a ton of bricks here in the EU institutions and, of course, across the continent among those in the European political sphere because Mario Draghi was seen as a bit of a superhero among the European political elite.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: He was of course the man who back in 2012 said those famous words that he would do whatever it takes to preserve the Euro, the common European currency. He's seen then as a very stable man, as a man who oozes credibility and he was the one pushing ahead with reforms that Italy needs to push ahead with in order to cash in from the EU's post-recovery fund. So you can imagine a sense of loss really in Europe among the European political sphere today. We heard from Paolo Gentiloni, that's the EU commissioner for Italy in charge of the economy, saying that this could bring about chaos over the next couple of months in Italy itself and create a backlash against the country. We saw Emmanuel Macron, the French president, saying that he was a great Italian statesman who had great trustworthiness because of course Europe's heading for a tricky difficult winter and it really needs stability right now, not instability with all the big challenges it faces. So all this uncertainty will not come as good news at all here for the EU capital for Brussels. Absolutely as you say made a very difficult time indeed made McMahon there reporting on the news going down quote like a ton of bricks. Well for the first time in 11 years the European Central Bank is raising its interest rates as Russia's war in Ukraine continues to rock the eurozone economy. The bank's governing council decided to hike up three benchmark deposit rates by 50 basis points after eight years of negative interest rates. Now the move follows the global push to combat soaring inflation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Christine Lagarde says that the central bank will also provide extra help to the bloc's more indebted nations with a new euro bond purchasing scheme to cap the rise in borrowing costs. Today, in line with our strong commitment to our price stability mandate, the governing council took further key steps to make sure that inflation returns to our 2% target over the medium term. We decided to raise the three key ECB interest rates by 50 basis points and approved the transmission protection instrument that I will refer to as TPI.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Russia has resumed gas supplies to Europe via the Nord Stream 1 pipeline, albeit at a significantly reduced level, as experts say that a winter energy crisis remains inevitable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: German authorities said that 40% of usual levels were expected to arrive today. Berlin had been concerned that scheduled maintenance work on the pipeline could signal the end of gas supplies altogether, Scheduled maintenance work on the pipeline could signal the end of gas supplies altogether, but the announcement has failed to alleviate fears among experts that Europe won't be heading towards an energy crisis later this year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Brussels and Berlin accuse Moscow of squeezing gas flows in retaliation for Western sanctions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: In the face of what it calls Russian blackmail, the European Union has faced backlash over its proposals to address energy security on the continent. Brussels has called on member states to cut back gas usage by 15% to shore up the bloc's winter gas stores. But the move has triggered stern opposition from several EU countries, Madrid saying that the plan doesn't account for less dependent states, while Lisbon reports that it's been having to increase gas usage due to drought problems in the country. A vote to approve the proposal will be held next Tuesday. For more analysis on what all of this means we can bring in Simone Tagliapietra now he is an energy policy expert at the Bruegel think tank. Good to have you with us. Welcome to the programme. So the gas is back on for now. This isn't crisis averted, though, is it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, I think we should not sit back and relax our flight because Nord Stream 1 has been reopened.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: I think Russia so far has been playing a very strategic game.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: For Russia, it makes more strategic sense to send low volumes of gas rather than a full cutoff, because a full cutoff can really catalyze action of European governments to cut demand and to make Europe more resilient.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So they hope we now sort of do some muggling through, not reducing gas gas demand and maybe cut the gas in the winter when we are more vulnerable. So we need to stick to our plans. We need to reduce our gas demand because an interruption can happen at any time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So if I understand your message correctly, you're saying to European member states, this is a trap. Don't fall for it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: I think that over the last weeks we have seen Russia cutting the gas supplies by two thirds to Europe and making a geopolitical use of these gas supplies. So we can certainly not trust Russia to continue to send these remaining one third of the supplies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We should get ready for a scenario which now is likely of a full interruption. And the only way to get prepared for Europe now is to reduce demand because we have done whatever it was possible to be done on the supply side. We have attracted a lot of LNG, liquefied natural gas, namely from the United States, to rebalance the lower volumes of Russian gas. Now the eventual gap will have to be filled by reducing demand. That's what we need to do now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: I mean yesterday it called on member states to reduce gas use by 15 percent. Less than 24 hours later we heard from Spain. We heard from Portugal saying they'd reject that. So you know what needs to happen here. Well of course while introducing these European targets you always have some countries that want to claim they are special and want to claim they need a different treatment but here I think we need to understand that reducing demand by 15% is something that would allow everybody and Europe overall to get a more efficient management of this. We would be better off all together if we are to go down this pathway indicated by the European Commission. And I think right what can be negotiated possibly is a compensation for those countries that are less dependent on Russian gas and can provide solidarity to other European countries that are more vulnerable. EU solidarity ensured by a compensation mechanism can be the way to go.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I certainly understand the logic in that proposal, but the fact of the matter is we've got Hungary's foreign minister in Moscow today saying that he wants to buy more Russian gas for Hungary.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So, I mean, at the end of the day, is this not the moment where European unity essentially crumbles in this war?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well this is I think the strategy from the very first day by Russia. Russia wants to weaponize energy in order to divide and rule and I think it will be fooled by the European Union, by the European countries, to let the Russian strategy prevail. If we fragment ourselves, if we go in different directions, Russia will prevail. They will weaken our domestic politics. And as a result, they will weaken our foreign policy stance in support of Ukraine and against the Russian aggression. So I think Europe should not go down this way and maintaining the unity is important even if we need to find solutions to guarantee that everybody is on board like in the case of Hungary.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The message there from Simone Tagliapietra, an energy policy expert at Bruegel think tank. Great to have you with us. Thanks for sharing your thoughts. At least two people have been killed and 19 others injured after

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Russian forces shelled a market in the northeastern city of Kharkiv. The regional governor says that a child is among the dead while four people are in a critical condition. As Moscow moves to capture territory in the south of the country, the British Ministry of Defence says it'll send more anti-tank weapons in the coming weeks to repel the invasion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, US intelligence says that up to 15,000 Russian troops have been killed since the war began.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And as the war in Ukraine continues, so too does disinformation about the conflict.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: A recent misleading post claims that Italians are angry at Ukrainian refugees for protesting and blocking a busy road near Rome.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Sophia in the Cube has been investigating.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Yes, Helena. Misinformation about Ukrainian refugees continues to spread online.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: This pro-Kremlin Telegram channel shared this video last week. In it we can see angry drivers pulling yellow-vested protesters off the road.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And this caption in Russian claims, and I quote, that Italian citizens are sick and tired of the stupid protest actions organized by Ukrainian refugees.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So as you can see, this post was viewed thousands of times and this Telegram channel has over 80,000 members. But this video is in fact misleading. Here in the cube we took a few stills from this video, did a reverse image search and we actually found that this video has appeared multiple times in local Italian media and it has nothing to do with the Ukraine war or with Ukrainian refugees. so what this actually was was a protest organized in June in Rome by extinction rebellion which is an environmental group and so we also found the original video on Twitter which also confirmed that this was an environmental protest and And according to Italian media, the protesters blocked this road to call for an end of all fossil fuels and demand that the Italian government start investing in clean energy, for example, in solar or wind power.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But this is not the first time that pro-Kremlin channels have actively tried to discredit Ukrainian refugees abroad.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: channels have actively tried to discredit Ukrainian refugees abroad. This week in the Cube, we debunked false claims that Ukrainian refugees were invited to stay at a former Nazi concentration camp in Germany. So, Helena, disinformation about refugees fleeing the Ukraine war has unfortunately followed them all the way to Western Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: All right, Sofia, they're setting the record straight for us. Sofia, thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, England are through to the semifinals of the Women's Euro 2022, beating Spain 2-1 on Wednesday night.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The hosts needed extra time to come from behind and book their place in the final four.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The Lionesses will find out their semifinal opponents on Friday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That's when Belgium take on 2020 Olympic finalist Sweden.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The tournament has already broken the record for being the most attended women's Euros to date.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, for more on this and other top sports stories, I'm joined now by sports reporter Cameron Hill.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Cameron, pretty exciting start to the knockout stages of the tournament. The hosts, I mean, I guess you could say they got the job done, but certainly I think it's fair to say that the Spanish side, I mean, they had them on the back foot really, didn't they?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Yeah, they did. It wasn't the most high quality encounter yesterday in Brighton, but in terms of excitement, it had it in spades.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Hosts England went into the game, considerable favourites, but they struggled to get going, especially in the first half, just struggled to make connections, make passes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It just didn't seem like it was there for them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Spain, on the other hand, they really had their tails up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: They were superb technically, especially in their passing, which Spain are known for anyway.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But they just weren't able to pull the trigger.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Every time they were in front of goal, it just wasn't on target for them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But in the second half, they rectified that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Esther Gonzalez, 10 minutes into the second, 45, getting that goal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And from then on, England really started to get back into the game.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Their work was now cut out for them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And Ella Toon found that equaliser on 84 minutes, sent it to extra time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: England on the front foot, and then that Georgia Stanway goal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Finally found space, midfield causing her all sorts of issues all night.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But she put her right boot to the ball, absolutely fired it, and it was a rocket.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Let me tell you, those sort of moments make the tournament and whatever happens in the rest of this tournament now that goal will live long in the memory they'll face either Belgium or Olympic silver medal medalist Sweden in the next round yeah it was certainly a nail-biter meanwhile it looks as though tennis star Novak Djokovic might not be allowed to play at the US Open later this year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Tell us more about that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Yeah, it's to do with his vaccination status.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The US policy at the moment is that unvaccinated non-citizens are not allowed into the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Djokovic is unvaccinated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We remember that whole saga at the start of the year with the Australian Open.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: He wasn't allowed to compete.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And he maintains that he's willing to miss tournaments if it comes to his vaccine status.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: He's already skipped tour events in the US this year at Indian Wells and Miami.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And although 21 Grand Slams, he's one off that record set by Nadal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It might turn his head and maybe he'll push to be at the tournament this year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But we're likely to hear a lot more on this situation and the tournament gets underway on the 29th of August.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: All right, that will be very interesting to see what happens there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, Cameron Hill, across all of the latest sports news for you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Cameron, great to have you on set. Thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, Italy's astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: has become the first European woman to take a walk in space.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Cristoforetti headed outside of the International Space Station alongside a Russian cosmonaut.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The duo will undertake several tasks, including installing platforms and workstation adapter hardware.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: They're also deploying 10 nanosatellites designed to collect radio electronics data in a mission which is expected to last up to seven hours.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Now, visitors to Paris will know that the French city is one of Europe's more expensive destinations but for some that is about to change as Europeans buckle under the weight of soaring inflation the euro sharp fall against the US dollar is good news for traveling Americans. Charlotte Lam has the story now. How about everybody else did you enjoy it? Summer in Paris is in full swing and Americans have returned to the French capital in hordes after two years of scrapped travel plans and rigorous COVID testing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: This time they're getting more bang for their buck with the euro almost matching the dollar.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: I've been to Europe before and I could definitely tell the difference.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Like it was way more expensive then, but now it's like the same, so.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: This has been glorious, because this is our fourth or fifth trip to Europe, and the exchange rates have always been like $1.35, $1.40 to the Euro.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Now, with them one-to-one, it seems like visiting a local vacation spot in the U.S.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Many travelers are escaping the heat by drinking fine wines, splurging on luxury goods, or treating themselves to lavish accommodation, while others plan a second trip for later in the year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Flights from the U.S US to Paris have increased by 11% compared to the same time in 2019.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: On average, American tourists mostly visiting in groups are spending 400 euros a day in France.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We leave you now with a no comment from Bogota, where military parades helped Colombia celebrate 212 years of national independence.

sentences.sentence: Thanks for watching Euronews tonight. Corea del Sur, luego de la invasión por parte de Corea del Norte, que ayudan a cimentar los sueyes se ha llegado. ¡Viva! ¡España! amistosas en el marco de la confianza y la...
